Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mantle Volatiles in an Emerging Ocean Basin: H2O, CO2, and He & Ar Isotopes in Basalts from the Gulf of Aden Spreading Center System
Award.AbstractNarration: Continental rifts and ocean spreading ridges are key places where volatile elements are exchanged between Earth's interior and its surface. Volatiles play a central role in the initiation of rifting/spreading, in volcanic evolution, and in associated geologic hazards. This research characterizes major volatile concentrations (H2O and CO2) and mantle source tracers (helium and argon isotopes) in magma erupted along the mid-ocean ridge in the Gulf of Aden in the Arabian Sea because this is a mid-ocean spreading center in its early stages of formation and evolution. The research also quantifies the flux of water coming from the mantle in the region. The Gulf of Aden is a unique locality for this work because it is a young ocean basin influenced by flow from the Afar mantle plume under the Horn of Africa. The plume affects the base of the Arabian lithosphere along the Red Sea and the western part of the Gulf of Aden; and its widespread influence is thought to result from the channeling of asthenospheric magma from the plume to the spreading center by rifts. However, the Afar Plume's apparent weaker penetration into the Gulf of Aden is not well understood and may be related to tectonic segmentation/discontinuities of the spreading ridge. The research will analyze submarine basalt glasses that were collected from previous oceanographic and sampling expeditions to the area for major element composition, volatile concentrations (CO2, H2O, Cl, F and S), and He and Ar isotopes. Initial results for Aden basalt glasses reveal a strong plume signal that may become rapidly attenuated with distance from the plume axis. Project goals are to determine how partial melting and degassing control mantle volatile signatures in young ocean spreading centers. Geochemical evidence (e.g., 3He/4He, 40Ar/36Ar, 4He/40Ar*, CO2/Nb, H2O/Ce) in about 40 basalt glasses from this region will be used to make this determination. Results of the study allow us to quantify variation in the volatile flux from the Afar plume and the upper mantle along the length of this emerging ocean basin between 44°E and 57°E. The results also provide a basic framework needed for geophysical and geodynamic models in terms of model input for regional and smaller scale variations in mantle composition, partial melting, and the heat and mass flux associated with the evolution from continental rifting to oceanic spreading. Broader impacts of the work include support of graduate and undergraduate students at two institutions, one in an EPSCoR state (Oklahoma), leverages existing samples collected with prior NSF support, and utilization of NSF-funded analytical facilities at Oregon State University and the University of Tulsa. Results will be described on institutional web pages as well as NSF-funded publically available data systems. Findings will also be incorporated into classes taught by the investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed at understanding the variation in volatile concentrations and isotopes in basalts erupted along a mid-ocean ridge during the early stages of ocean basin formation and evolution. We analyzed quenched submarine basalt glasses from the Gulf of Aden region (including Gulf of Tadjoura and Asal Rift basalts) for major volatiles (carbon dioxide and water) and helium isotope compositions, as well as major elements and minor volatiles Cl, S and F. The Gulf of Aden is a young (<30 million year old) ocean basin at the boundary of the Arabian and Somalian tectonic plates (Figure 1), and is a site of mantle plume-spreading ridge interaction. Previous geochemical and geophysical work established that deep mantle upwelling is centered beneath a plate triple junction in Afar.

We discovered that basalts from the Gulf of Aden have surprisingly high H2O contents. H2O is typically expressed as a ratio with cerium, since they have similar geochemical behavior during mantle melting.  H2O/Ce in mid-ocean ridge basalt (MORB) glasses is fairly constant globally at about 200+/-50 except for a few places such as the northern Mid-Atlantic ridge (MAR) and Gakkel ridge in the western Arctic. H2O/Ce for Gulf of Aden basalts ranges from 240 to 530, with an average over 350.   We are now certain that high H2O and H2O/Ce is a feature of the mantle source, and not due to shallow assimilation of altered crustal materials because our high precision microprobe analyses show that chlorine contents and Cl/K are not elevated, as would be expected by assimilation.  Our computed values for the mantle's H2O contents beneath the Gulf of Aden spreading centers (Figure 2) are about 1.5 to 2 times greater than most parts of the mid-ocean ridge (Michael, 1988; 1995), and are especially high (as expected) at the western end of the Gulf of Aden near Afar which is influenced by the enriched mantle plume.  High H2O/Ce might be related to the presence of subcontinental lithospheric mantle in the mantle source since this is a recently rifted area: something that it shares with the Gakkel ridge and the northernmost mid-Atlantic Ridge, which is also a relatively recently rifted area and a restricted ocean basin.  However, high H2O/Ce is not strongly correlated with other aspects of mantle chemistry such as radiogenic isotope ratios or incompatible element ratios.

As part of this project we also completed a global study of MORB (including several from the eastern sector of the Gulf of Aden) that are so highly depleted in incompatible elements that they never reached volatile saturation, and therefore represent extremely rare undegassed MORBs that retain their initial mantle volatile inventory. Our detailed investigation of their CO2, H2O, He and highly incompatible trace element abundances established trace element proxies for inferring primary magmatic CO2 concentrations. We found that CO2/Ba ratios are effectively the most uniform indicator (CO2/Ba=105+/-9) so that mantle-derived CO2 contents of MORBs can be estimated using Ba contents even after they have lost their CO2 by degassing. We also observed very strong correlation between helium and highly incompatible elements (C, K, Rb, Ba, Nb, Th, U) in the undegassed MORBs that revealed, for the first time using a suite of natural basalts, that helium behaves as the most incompatible element during mantle melting (Graham et al., 2016).

The project supported two undergraduate students and introduced them to scientific research.  Partly as a result of their involvement in this project, they have decided to pursue scientific research at the graduate level, and possibly as a career.  Timothy Witham is now a Ph.D student in geology and Lauren Haygood will start working on her M.S. degree in 2019.  They gained valuable analytical experience working in our microanalytical laboratory.  The project also supported the principal investigator, Peter Michael, to make fully operational the newly-installed electron microprobe (a significant improvement to our old microprobe) at The University of Tulsa, which will help promote international and national collaborations and scientific research in Oklahoma, an EPSCoR state.

A further impact of this study is that we were able to make the most refined estimate to date of the global flux of carbon dioxide from mid-ocean ridges (Michael and Graham, 2015) and to show that annual flux from ridges globally is less than 1% of anthropogenic outputs.
